title: How to Make a Volcano Erupt

steps.headline: Find a plastic soda bottle.
steps.description: The size of your bottle will determine the size of your volcano.

steps.headline: Grab a square cardboard box that is as tall as your soda bottle.
steps.description: Cut out all the sides except 1, which you will use to support your bottle.

steps.headline: Tape the plastic bottle to the cardboard, both to the remaining side and to the bottom.
steps.description: Add some cardboard supports to make the bottle as sturdy as possible. Cut out several strips of cardboard that are 3 inches by 6 inches (7.5 by 15cm) for the supports. Tape them with masking tape, electrical tape or duct tape. Avoid packing tape because it is too slick.

steps.headline: Mix your dough.
steps.description:
Combine 6 cups (0.75kg) of flour, 2 cups (0.58kg) of salt, 2 cups (0.47l) of water and 4 tbsp. (59ml) of cooking oil. Use your hands to knead the dough until smooth. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/1c\/Make-a-Volcano-Erupt-Step-4Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Volcano-Erupt-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/1c\/Make-a-Volcano-Erupt-Step-4Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Volcano-Erupt-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Pile the dough around the bottle to form a mountain.
steps.description: Allow it to dry once the volcano is sculpted.

steps.headline: Paint the dough with tempera paints.
steps.description: For example, you may want to paint the volcano brown with green near the bottom. Illustrate the eruption by painting red lava flows down the side.

steps.headline: Place a funnel in the mouth of the volcano, so that it reaches into your plastic bottle.
Mix 1 tsp.
steps.description: (4.9ml) of dish soap, 1 oz. (29.6ml) of vinegar and several drops of red and yellow food coloring in a separate container.

steps.headline: Ready your volcano for the eruption.
steps.description: Pour in the vinegar mixture. Wait and watch as the vinegar and baking soda combine to form carbonic acid.

steps.headline: Remove the bottle through the top of the volcano or by disconnecting the supporting side of the cardboard from the dough.
Buy a 2 l (67.6oz) bottle of carbonated soda.
Make a cardboard tray and cut a hole in it that is equal to the size of the 2 l bottle.
steps.description: Use very sturdy cardboard for this tray. You can also use several thick sheets of cardboard for a stronger base.

steps.headline: Stick the bottle of soda into the cardboard support.
steps.description: Cover the portion of the bottle above the support with aluminum foil.

steps.headline: Buy a can of insulating foam for cracks.
steps.description: You want the kind that sprays with a foam and hardens. You may want to try Great Stuff Insulating Foam Sealant.

steps.headline: Spray around your bottle to create a mountain.
steps.description: Once your basic shape is formed, allow it to dry.

steps.headline: Paint the dried insulating foam after it has hardened.
Unscrew the lid on the soda bottle.
steps.description: Place a small piece of paper atop it.

steps.headline: Create a cylinder with another piece of paper.
Ready your audience for the eruption.
steps.description: Quickly remove the paper that is lying flat over the top of the soda bottle. The 4 Mentos should pour into the bottle starting the explosion. The porous surface of the Mentos causes the rapid formation of carbon dioxide. This chemical reaction produces foam. Remove your 2 l bottle of soda from the bottom of the cardboard. Insert another bottle and do it again.

text:
Baking Soda and Dough Volcano Find a plastic soda bottle. The size of your bottle will determine the size of your volcano. Grab a square cardboard box that is as tall as your soda bottle. Cut out all the sides except 1, which you will use to support your bottle. Tape the plastic bottle to the cardboard, both to the remaining side and to the bottom. Add some cardboard supports to make the bottle as sturdy as possible. Cut out several strips of cardboard that are 3 inches by 6 inches (7.5 by 15cm) for the supports. Tape them with masking tape, electrical tape or duct tape. Avoid packing tape because it is too slick. Mix your dough. Combine 6 cups (0.75kg) of flour, 2 cups (0.58kg) of salt, 2 cups (0.47l) of water and 4 tbsp. (59ml) of cooking oil. Use your hands to knead the dough until smooth. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/1c\/Make-a-Volcano-Erupt-Step-4Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Volcano-Erupt-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/1c\/Make-a-Volcano-Erupt-Step-4Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Volcano-Erupt-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Pile the dough around the bottle to form a mountain. Allow it to dry once the volcano is sculpted. Paint the dough with tempera paints. For example, you may want to paint the volcano brown with green near the bottom. Illustrate the eruption by painting red lava flows down the side. Place a funnel in the mouth of the volcano, so that it reaches into your plastic bottle. Add 2 tbsp. (28g) of baking soda. Mix 1 tsp. (4.9ml) of dish soap, 1 oz. (29.6ml) of vinegar and several drops of red and yellow food coloring in a separate container. Ready your volcano for the eruption. Pour in the vinegar mixture. Wait and watch as the vinegar and baking soda combine to form carbonic acid. Remove the bottle through the top of the volcano or by disconnecting the supporting side of the cardboard from the dough. Empty it and start again. Mentos and Foam Volcano Buy a 2 l (67.6oz) bottle of carbonated soda. Make a cardboard tray and cut a hole in it that is equal to the size of the 2 l bottle. Use very sturdy cardboard for this tray. You can also use several thick sheets of cardboard for a stronger base. Stick the bottle of soda into the cardboard support. Cover the portion of the bottle above the support with aluminum foil. Buy a can of insulating foam for cracks. You want the kind that sprays with a foam and hardens. You may want to try Great Stuff Insulating Foam Sealant. Spray around your bottle to create a mountain. Once your basic shape is formed, allow it to dry. Paint the dried insulating foam after it has hardened. Unscrew the lid on the soda bottle. Place a small piece of paper atop it. Create a cylinder with another piece of paper. Drop 4 Mentos into the cylinder. Ready your audience for the eruption. Quickly remove the paper that is lying flat over the top of the soda bottle. The 4 Mentos should pour into the bottle starting the explosion. The porous surface of the Mentos causes the rapid formation of carbon dioxide. This chemical reaction produces foam. Remove your 2 l bottle of soda from the bottom of the cardboard. Insert another bottle and do it again.
sentences: Baking Soda and Dough Volcano Find a plastic soda bottle.
The size of your bottle will determine the size of your volcano.
Grab a square cardboard box that is as tall as your soda bottle.
Cut out all the sides except 1, which you will use to support your bottle.
Tape the plastic bottle to the cardboard, both to the remaining side and to the bottom.
Add some cardboard supports to make the bottle as sturdy as possible.
Cut out several strips of cardboard that are 3 inches by 6 inches (7.5 by 15cm) for the supports.
Tape them with masking tape, electrical tape or duct tape.
Avoid packing tape because it is too slick.
Mix your dough.
Combine 6 cups (0.75kg) of flour, 2 cups (0.58kg) of salt, 2 cups (0.47l) of water and 4 tbsp.
(59ml) of cooking oil.
Use your hands to knead the dough until smooth.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/1c\/Make-a-Volcano-Erupt-Step-4Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Volcano-Erupt-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/1c\/Make-a-Volcano-Erupt-Step-4Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Volcano-Erupt-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Pile the dough around the bottle to form a mountain.
Allow it to dry once the volcano is sculpted.
Paint the dough with tempera paints.
For example, you may want to paint the volcano brown with green near the bottom.
Illustrate the eruption by painting red lava flows down the side.
Place a funnel in the mouth of the volcano, so that it reaches into your plastic bottle.
Add 2 tbsp.
(28g) of baking soda.
Mix 1 tsp.
(4.9ml) of dish soap, 1 oz.
(29.6ml) of vinegar and several drops of red and yellow food coloring in a separate container.
Ready your volcano for the eruption.
Pour in the vinegar mixture.
Wait and watch as the vinegar and baking soda combine to form carbonic acid.
Remove the bottle through the top of the volcano or by disconnecting the supporting side of the cardboard from the dough.
Empty it and start again.
Mentos and Foam Volcano Buy a 2 l (67.6oz) bottle of carbonated soda.
Make a cardboard tray and cut a hole in it that is equal to the size of the 2 l bottle.
Use very sturdy cardboard for this tray.
You can also use several thick sheets of cardboard for a stronger base.
Stick the bottle of soda into the cardboard support.
Cover the portion of the bottle above the support with aluminum foil.
Buy a can of insulating foam for cracks.
You want the kind that sprays with a foam and hardens.
You may want to try Great Stuff Insulating Foam Sealant.
Spray around your bottle to create a mountain.
Once your basic shape is formed, allow it to dry.
Paint the dried insulating foam after it has hardened.
Unscrew the lid on the soda bottle.
Place a small piece of paper atop it.
Create a cylinder with another piece of paper.
Drop 4 Mentos into the cylinder.
Ready your audience for the eruption.
Quickly remove the paper that is lying flat over the top of the soda bottle.
The 4 Mentos should pour into the bottle starting the explosion.
The porous surface of the Mentos causes the rapid formation of carbon dioxide.
This chemical reaction produces foam.
Remove your 2 l bottle of soda from the bottom of the cardboard.
Insert another bottle and do it again.
